<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
Editor's Note
</p>
</td>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: bottom" valign="bottom" width="33%">

<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>It’s the first day of August, which also happens to be the month when I turn 30. “<em>How does it feel</em>?” you’re supposed to ask.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It feels great, thanks for asking. They don’t teach you this in school, but getting older is a blast. Each day you live you understand more about how the world actually works, connecting dots you never thought belonged on the same page. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But the greatest joy has been learning about myself. I know how much sleep I need to be well-rested. I know that I hate the smell of licorice. I know my strengths, and I know what to improve.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Sure, turning 30 has its downsides. To quote Bo Burnham, “My stupid friends are having stupid children.” Those boys' trips to New Orleans are less frequent. Responsibilities are piling up. I need to wear glasses.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But that’s OK. Priorities change. And if all goes well over the next decade, I’ll be writing this same note at 40 from the suburbs, prepping for a glorious Sunday of coaching Little League and raking leaves.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal Freyman</p>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;color: #353535; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 22px; table-layout: auto; width: 100%; border: none;" width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
Q&A
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Icebreakers with...Build-A-Bear CEO Sharon Price John
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/30/icebreakers-withbuildabear-ceo-sharon-price-john?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Headshot of Sharon Price John" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81OTkwL3NoYXJvbl9wcmljZV9qb2huLmpwZWciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Our Tennessee</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Build-A-Bear Workshop turns 25 next year (feeling old?), and the brand has been growing up with its audience. In addition to browsing the typical heart-stuffed plush, customers can head to the age-gated section of Build-A-Bear’s site, <a href="https://www.buildabear.com/the-bear-cave?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Bear Cave</a>, and nab a Deadpool panda. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So after buying 14 Pandapools, we caught up with Build-A-Bear CEO Sharon Price John to learn more about how the company known for its childhood mall magic has evolved.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Chicken and egg question for you: Did you see increased interest from an older demographic and create more products for them, or did you create those products and the older demographic came?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We started to see an expansion in interest [among older demographics] when we got closer to 20 years old. So five-ish years ago, there was a natural expansion. And that happens a lot in the toy industry. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The key is how do you use it as a flywheel and not just a blip in time? As soon as we started to see the data, we started leaning in with more licensing, a little more edgy marketing, making sure that we were really appropriate online for digital natives. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Because you want a bigger market. The kids market is hard. It’s always new customers. It churns all the time. It’s what we call a “leaky bucket.” Adult customers are a bigger market that buys less often but is more stable. Plus, it elevates you from a pop culture perspective.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>The in-person aspect of Build-A-Bear stores feels like such a big part of the magic of creating your bear. How have you dealt with that during the pandemic?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We had to shift hard toward e-commerce. It was our only source of consistent revenue as our stores shut down. We had to furlough the vast majority of our organization and do what many companies did. That’s never simple or easy, especially when you’re a company that prides itself on adding a little more heart to life.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But we fortuitously put a number of updates in place that we had already been planning. Buy online and ship to store, buy online and pick up in store, we completed a deal with Shipt for same-day delivery...so we were able to maintain a good cash flow.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">To your point, experience is a benchmark of Build-A-Bear, and it’s almost like we were experiential retail before experiential retail was cool. So how do we make sure our online experience has connectivity back to what we do in the store? For that, we created a Bear Builder Configurator that takes you through the process (pick your bear, pick your outfit, put a sound in), and you can do a heart ceremony. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Zooming out to the toy industry, are you seeing any trends that we should keep an eye on?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">One is <em>experience</em> now that we’re on the other side. I think you’re going to see a pretty good horizon on that, on people re-engaging and getting out and doing fun things.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Is there a particular licensed bear that’s been super popular?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We don’t rank the products like that, but Baby Yoda’s a phenomenon, not just with us but across the board. Harry Potter as you might imagine is one of the biggest powerhouse licenses out there, and then most recently, we launched <em>Animal Crossing: New Horizons</em>. We looked into that because of so much social media saying, “Please, please, please make Animal Crossing.”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity.</em></p>

ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">

<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Into the Metaverse We Go
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/30/mark-zuckerberg-wants-facebook-become-metaverse-company-mean?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Fortnite parent Epic Games launches publishing label" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNzQvZXBpY19nYW1lc19mb3J0bml0ZS5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Epic Games</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">When he’s not throwing spears or cloning Snapchat, Mark Zuckerberg dreams about the metaverse. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">“In the coming years, I expect people will transition from seeing us primarily as a social media company to seeing us as a metaverse company,” he <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-07-29/mark-zuckerberg-explains-metaverse-vision-to-facebook-fb-investors-analysts?sref=KkPzpZvz" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said</a> on Facebook’s earnings call Wednesday.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">He’s serious. On Monday, Facebook announced it was forming a metaverse product group to bring Zuck’s vision from science fiction to reali—er, virtual reality. </p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1">
<span>The group’s lead, Andrew Bosworth (Boz), </span><span><a href="https://www.facebook.com/boz/posts/10113772424752191?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wrote</a></span><span> that Facebook wanted to “remove the limitations of physics” in order to allow people to connect with one another in virtual spaces. </span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>And if you didn’t think FB was serious about the metaverse, Boz’s post linked to a site with more than 700 open jobs.</span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">But what <em>is</em> the metaverse?</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Well, here’s the bad news: Not even the guy who popularized it can fully explain it. Venture capitalist Matthew Ball, whose <a href="https://www.matthewball.vc/all/themetaverse?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">writing</a> on the metaverse has influenced Zuck and other tech thinkers, calls it a “successor state to the mobile internet” but stops short of slapping down an actual definition. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">He does, however, identify key attributes of the metaverse.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>Things will happen “live” just as they do in real life. You can’t pause or rewind anything.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>The metaverse will be a fully functioning economy, so you can buy, sell, and invest in things as you would in the physical world.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1">
<span>It will have unprecedented interoperability, meaning you can bring your virtual self and your assets (say, a skin from </span><span><em>Fortnite</em></span><span>) to every experience without compatibility issues. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>The backstory: </strong>The term “metaverse” first showed up in Neal Stephenson’s sci-fi novel <em>Snow Crash </em>in 1992, and was built upon by other science fiction thinkers like Ernest Cline, who depicted a version of the metaverse in his book <em>Ready Player One</em>. Metaverse philosophizing picked up during the pandemic, when people started hanging out in video games like <em>Fortnite</em>, <em>Roblox</em>, and <em>Animal Crossing </em>instead of IRL. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">And yet the metaverse is so tantalizing, so esoteric, that it could mean everything...and nothing.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">When Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella said this week his company was building “the enterprise metaverse” in reference to the company’s cloud-computing services, he was mocked on social media for indiscriminately using a buzzword.  </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Some critics say that while the metaverse idea <em>sounds </em>cool, it may not be the <a href="https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2021/07/facebooks-metaverse-gambit-is-a-distraction-from-its-deep-seated-problems/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">logical next step</a> in the evolution of social media. Others say talking about futuristic concepts could be a tool for Zuck to keep investors excited about the company’s deep investments in AR and VR...and distracted from its current antitrust battles.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Bottom line: </strong>The metaverse won’t magically appear one day. If it does come into existence, it’ll be a decades-long process involving thousands of companies building the hardware, content, currencies, and other components that together constitute a metaverse. Just as Facebook conquered the internet, it wants to stake a claim in whatever the next version of that will be. </p>

</div>
</td>
</tr>


<tr>
<td align="left" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 10px 0px; word-break: break-word;">

Open House
</h1>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the only newsletter section that will make you seriously consider buying an entire home just for the yellow bathtub. We’ll give you a few facts about a listing and you try to guess the price.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><img src="https://media.giphy.com/media/WXpCXJwGyYTYWnk8qQ/giphy.gif" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="New Mexico listing carousel: Front of house, living room, kitchen, bathrooms" data-source="Zillow" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>Zillow</em> </small></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In Clovis, New Mexico, a town 15 minutes west of the Texas border, a <a href="https://www.zillow.com/homedetails/1400-Piedmont-Dr-Clovis-NM-88101/194281779_zpid/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">home</a> exists with so much wood inside of it that you’d be able to dismantle it and sell it for parts if lumber prices go up again. But it’s got so much more than nicely finished timber:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>4 beds, 5 baths</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Master bedroom balcony</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Plenty of built-in storage</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>The widest variety of bathrooms</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much for your ’70s dream house? Scroll to the bottom of the newsletter to find out.</p>

style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eIt’s the first day of August, which also happens to be the month when I turn 30. “\u003cem\u003eHow does it feel\u003c/em\u003e?” you’re supposed to ask.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt feels great, thanks for asking. They don’t teach you this in school, but getting older is a blast. Each day you live you understand more about how the world actually works, connecting dots you never thought belonged on the same page. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut the greatest joy has been learning about myself. I know how much sleep I need to be well-rested. I know that I hate the smell of licorice. I know my strengths, and I know what to improve.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSure, turning 30 has its downsides. To quote Bo Burnham, “My stupid friends are having stupid children.” Those boys' trips to New Orleans are less frequent. Responsibilities are piling up. I need to wear glasses.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut that’s OK. Priorities change. And if all goes well over the next decade, I’ll be writing this same note at 40 from the suburbs, prepping for a glorious Sunday of coaching Little League and raking leaves.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e—Neal Freyman\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81OTkwL3NoYXJvbl9wcmljZV9qb2huLmpwZWciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eOur Tennessee\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBuild-A-Bear Workshop turns 25 next year (feeling old?), and the brand has been growing up with its audience. In addition to browsing the typical heart-stuffed plush, customers can head to the age-gated section of Build-A-Bear’s site, \u003ca href=\"https://www.buildabear.com/the-bear-cave?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eThe Bear Cave\u003c/a\u003e, and nab a Deadpool panda. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo after buying 14 Pandapools, we caught up with Build-A-Bear CEO Sharon Price John to learn more about how the company known for its childhood mall magic has evolved.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eChicken and egg question for you: Did you see increased interest from an older demographic and create more products for them, or did you create those products and the older demographic came?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe started to see an expansion in interest [among older demographics] when we got closer to 20 years old. So five-ish years ago, there was a natural expansion. And that happens a lot in the toy industry. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe key is how do you use it as a flywheel and not just a blip in time? As soon as we started to see the data, we started leaning in with more licensing, a little more edgy marketing, making sure that we were really appropriate online for digital natives. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBecause you want a bigger market. The kids market is hard. It’s always new customers. It churns all the time. It’s what we call a “leaky bucket.” Adult customers are a bigger market that buys less often but is more stable. Plus, it elevates you from a pop culture perspective.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe in-person aspect of Build-A-Bear stores feels like such a big part of the magic of creating your bear. How have you dealt with that during the pandemic?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe had to shift hard toward e-commerce. It was our only source of consistent revenue as our stores shut down. We had to furlough the vast majority of our organization and do what many companies did. That’s never simple or easy, especially when you’re a company that prides itself on adding a little more heart to life.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut we fortuitously put a number of updates in place that we had already been planning. Buy online and ship to store, buy online and pick up in store, we completed a deal with Shipt for same-day delivery...so we were able to maintain a good cash flow.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eTo your point, experience is a benchmark of Build-A-Bear, and it’s almost like we were experiential retail before experiential retail was cool. So how do we make sure our online experience has connectivity back to what we do in the store? For that, we created a Bear Builder Configurator that takes you through the process (pick your bear, pick your outfit, put a sound in), and you can do a heart ceremony. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eZooming out to the toy industry, are you seeing any trends that we should keep an eye on?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOne is \u003cem\u003eexperience\u003c/em\u003e now that we’re on the other side. I think you’re going to see a pretty good horizon on that, on people re-engaging and getting out and doing fun things.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIs there a particular licensed bear that’s been super popular?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe don’t rank the products like that, but Baby Yoda’s a phenomenon, not just with us but across the board. Harry Potter as you might imagine is one of the biggest powerhouse licenses out there, and then most recently, we launched \u003cem\u003eAnimal Crossing: New Horizons\u003c/em\u003e. We looked into that because of so much social media saying, “Please, please, please make Animal Crossing.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F30%2Ficebreakers-withbuildabear-ceo-sharon-price-john\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;\"\u003e\n \n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd class=\"column\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nInto the Metaverse We Go\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/30/mark-zuckerberg-wants-facebook-become-metaverse-company-mean?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Fortnite parent Epic Games launches publishing label\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNzQvZXBpY19nYW1lc19mb3J0bml0ZS5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eEpic Games\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhen he’s not throwing spears or cloning Snapchat, Mark Zuckerberg dreams about the metaverse. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e“In the coming years, I expect people will transition from seeing us primarily as a social media company to seeing us as a metaverse company,” he \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-07-29/mark-zuckerberg-explains-metaverse-vision-to-facebook-fb-investors-analysts?sref=KkPzpZvz\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid\u003c/a\u003e on Facebook’s earnings call Wednesday.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eHe’s serious. On Monday, Facebook announced it was forming a metaverse product group to bring Zuck’s vision from science fiction to reali—er, virtual reality. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe group’s lead, Andrew Bosworth (Boz), \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/boz/posts/10113772424752191?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrote\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e that Facebook wanted to “remove the limitations of physics” in order to allow people to connect with one another in virtual spaces. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAnd if you didn’t think FB was serious about the metaverse, Boz’s post linked to a site with more than 700 open jobs.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eBut what \u003cem\u003eis\u003c/em\u003e the metaverse?\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWell, here’s the bad news: Not even the guy who popularized it can fully explain it. Venture capitalist Matthew Ball, whose \u003ca href=\"https://www.matthewball.vc/all/themetaverse?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewriting\u003c/a\u003e on the metaverse has influenced Zuck and other tech thinkers, calls it a “successor state to the mobile internet” but stops short of slapping down an actual definition. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eHe does, however, identify key attributes of the metaverse.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThings will happen “live” just as they do in real life. You can’t pause or rewind anything.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe metaverse will be a fully functioning economy, so you can buy, sell, and invest in things as you would in the physical world.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIt will have unprecedented interoperability, meaning you can bring your virtual self and your assets (say, a skin from \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eFortnite\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e) to every experience without compatibility issues. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eThe term “metaverse” first showed up in Neal Stephenson’s sci-fi novel \u003cem\u003eSnow Crash \u003c/em\u003ein 1992, and was built upon by other science fiction thinkers like Ernest Cline, who depicted a version of the metaverse in his book \u003cem\u003eReady Player One\u003c/em\u003e. Metaverse philosophizing picked up during the pandemic, when people started hanging out in video games like \u003cem\u003eFortnite\u003c/em\u003e, \u003cem\u003eRoblox\u003c/em\u003e, and \u003cem\u003eAnimal Crossing \u003c/em\u003einstead of IRL. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAnd yet the metaverse is so tantalizing, so esoteric, that it could mean everything...and nothing.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhen Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella said this week his company was building “the enterprise metaverse” in reference to the company’s cloud-computing services, he was mocked on social media for indiscriminately using a buzzword.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSome critics say that while the metaverse idea \u003cem\u003esounds \u003c/em\u003ecool, it may not be the \u003ca href=\"https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2021/07/facebooks-metaverse-gambit-is-a-distraction-from-its-deep-seated-problems/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elogical next step\u003c/a\u003e in the evolution of social media. Others say talking about futuristic concepts could be a tool for Zuck to keep investors excited about the company’s deep investments in AR and VR...and distracted from its current antitrust battles.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThe metaverse won’t magically appear one day. If it does come into existence, it’ll be a decades-long process involving thousands of companies building the hardware, content, currencies, and other components that together constitute a metaverse. Just as Facebook conquered the internet, it wants to stake a claim in whatever the next version of that will be. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F30%2Fmark-zuckerberg-wants-facebook-become-metaverse-company-mean\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block;
